documents.title: Architecture Overview

sections.heading: Factory 1: Data Foundry
sections.content: **Purpose:** Transform raw clinical data files into a queryable database. | Input | Processing | Output | |-------|------------|--------| | SAS7BDAT files | SAS Reader → Parquet conversion | DuckDB database |

sections.heading: Key Components
sections.content: - **SASReader**: Reads SAS7BDAT files using - **DuckDBLoader**: Loads Parquet files into DuckDB - **SchemaTracker**: Tracks table versions and changes

sections.heading: Supported Datasets
sections.content: | Type | Common Tables | |------|--------------| | **SDTM** | DM, AE, CM, LB, VS, EX, MH | | **ADaM** | ADSL, ADAE, ADLB, ADTTE, ADEFF | Detailed Factory 1 documentation →

sections.heading: Factory 2: Metadata Refinery
sections.content: **Purpose:** Transform Excel specifications into structured metadata with human oversight. | Input | Processing | Output | |-------|------------|--------| | Excel specs | Parse → CDISC enrich → Approve | Golden Metadata JSON |

sections.heading: Key Components
sections.content: - **ExcelParser**: Parses SDTM/ADaM specification files - **CDISCLibrary**: Enriches with CDISC Controlled Terminology - **ApprovalWorkflow**: Human-in-the-loop validation - **MetadataStore**: Stores approved metadata

sections.heading: Human-in-the-Loop
sections.content: !!! important "Approval Required" All metadata mappings require human approval before use. This ensures accuracy and audit compliance. Detailed Factory 2 documentation →

sections.heading: Factory 3: Dictionary Plant
sections.content: **Purpose:** Build fuzzy matching indexes from live data. | Input | Processing | Output | |-------|------------|--------| | DuckDB data | Value scanning → Index building | Fuzzy indexes |

sections.heading: Key Components
sections.content: - **ValueScanner**: Profiles unique values in each column - **FuzzyMatcher**: RapidFuzz-based term matching - **SchemaMapper**: Maps columns to concepts

sections.heading: Fuzzy Matching Capabilities
sections.content: - Handles typos: → - Resolves synonyms: → - UK/US spellings: → , Detailed Factory 3 documentation →

sections.heading: Factory 3.5: MedDRA Integration
sections.content: **Purpose:** Provide medical terminology hierarchy support. | Input | Processing | Output | |-------|------------|--------| | MedDRA files | Loader → Hierarchy builder | MedDRA Lookup |

sections.heading: Hierarchy Levels
sections.content: Detailed Factory 3.5 documentation →

sections.heading: Factory 4: Inference Engine
sections.content: **Purpose:** Process natural language queries and return structured results.

sections.heading: The 9-Step Pipeline
sections.content: | Step | Component | Purpose | |------|-----------|---------| | 1 | InputSanitizer | Block PHI/PII, SQL injection | | 2 | EntityExtractor | Extract clinical terms | | 3 | TableResolver | Select table, apply clinical rules | | 4 | ContextBuilder | Prepare LLM context | | 5 | SQLGenerator | Generate DuckDB SQL | | 6 | SQLValidator | Validate SQL safety | | 7 | Executor | Execute against DuckDB | | 8 | ConfidenceScorer | Calculate confidence | | 9 | ExplanationGenerator | Build human response | Detailed Factory 4 documentation →

sections.heading: 1. AI as Translator
sections.content: The AI translates natural language to SQL. It does **not** perform calculations:

sections.heading: 2. Deterministic Execution
sections.content: All calculations are performed by DuckDB, ensuring reproducible results.

sections.heading: 3. Transparency
sections.content: Every answer includes: - The SQL query executed - The table and columns used - Any assumptions made - A confidence score

sections.heading: 4. Security First
sections.content: - PHI/PII detection and blocking - SQL injection prevention - Read-only database access - Full audit logging

sections.heading: SQL Injection Prevention
sections.content: Multi-layer SQL injection protection: 1. **Pattern Detection**: Blocks common injection patterns 2. **Query Parsing**: Validates SQL syntax 3. **Parameterization**: Never concatenates user input into SQL **Implementation:**

sections.heading: Prompt Injection Prevention
sections.content: Prevents attempts to manipulate the LLM:

sections.heading: Pre-Execution Checks
sections.content: Before any SQL runs, it must pass: | Check | Description | |-------|-------------| | **Syntax Valid** | Parses without errors | | **Tables Exist** | All referenced tables are real | | **Columns Exist** | All referenced columns are real | | **Read-Only** | No INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, DROP | | **No Subversions** | No dangerous patterns |

documents.title: Audit Trail

sections.heading: Overview
sections.content: Every user action is logged with: - Who performed the action - When it occurred - What was requested - What was returned - How long it took

sections.heading: Query Events
sections.content: | Field | Description | |-------|-------------| | timestamp | ISO 8601 timestamp | | event_type | "query" | | user_id | Authenticated user | | session_id | Conversation ID | | query | Original question | | sql_generated | Generated SQL | | tables_accessed | Tables queried | | columns_used | Columns in query | | result_count | Rows returned | | confidence_score | 0-100 score | | execution_time_ms | Processing time |

sections.heading: Authentication Events
sections.content: | Field | Description | |-------|-------------| | timestamp | ISO 8601 timestamp | | event_type | "login", "logout", "failed_login" | | user_id | Attempted user | | ip_address | Client IP | | success | true/false | | failure_reason | If applicable |

sections.heading: System Events
sections.content: | Field | Description | |-------|-------------| | timestamp | ISO 8601 timestamp | | event_type | "startup", "shutdown", "config_change" | | performed_by | User or "system" | | details | Event specifics |

sections.heading: Retention
sections.content: | Log Type | Default Retention | |----------|-------------------| | Query logs | 7 years | | Auth logs | 3 years | | System logs | 1 year |

sections.heading: Format
sections.content: - JSON Lines (.jsonl) - One record per line - Timestamped filenames - Compressed after 7 days

sections.heading: 21 CFR Part 11
sections.content: | Requirement | SAGE Implementation | |-------------|---------------------| | 11.10(b) - Generate accurate copies | Export to CSV/PDF | | 11.10(c) - Record protection | Read-only logs, backups | | 11.10(e) - Audit trail | Comprehensive logging | | 11.10(g) - Authority checks | RBAC enforcement | | 11.10(k) - Device checks | Session management |

sections.heading: EU Annex 11
sections.content: | Requirement | SAGE Implementation | |-------------|---------------------| | 9 - Audit trail | Query/auth logging | | 12.1 - Security | Access controls | | 12.4 - Audit trail | Cannot modify logs |

sections.heading: Immutability
sections.content: Logs cannot be modified after creation: - Append-only file format - Hash chains for verification - Regular backup to secure storage

sections.heading: Best Practices
sections.content: 1. **Regular Review**: Check logs weekly for anomalies 2. **Secure Storage**: Store backups off-site 3. **Access Control**: Limit who can view logs 4. **Retention Policy**: Follow regulatory requirements 5. **Integrity Checks**: Verify hash chains regularly

sections.heading: Next Steps
sections.content: - Data Integrity - Access Controls - Validation Summary

documents.title: Validation Summary

sections.heading: GAMP 5 Classification
sections.content: **Category 4: Configured Software Product** SAGE is a configurable software product that: - Uses standard commercial components (DuckDB, FastAPI, React) - Is configured for clinical trial data analysis - Does not require custom programming for basic use - Follows risk-based validation approach

sections.heading: Applicable Regulations
sections.content: | Regulation | Applicability | |------------|---------------| | 21 CFR Part 11 | Electronic records, audit trails | | EU Annex 11 | Computerized systems | | ICH E6(R2) | Good Clinical Practice | | GAMP 5 | Validation approach |

documents.title: Confidence Scorer

sections.heading: Overview
sections.content: **File:** **Class:** **Purpose:** Provide transparency about answer reliability

sections.heading: Why Confidence Scoring?
sections.content: Clinical data queries need reliability indicators: - Users need to know when to trust results - Auditors need traceability - Low confidence triggers review

sections.heading: Score Components
sections.content: | Component | Weight | Measures | |-----------|--------|----------| | **Entity Resolution** | 40% | How well user terms matched data | | **Metadata Coverage** | 30% | How well columns are documented | | **Execution Success** | 20% | Query executed without errors | | **Result Sanity** | 10% | Results are reasonable |

sections.heading: Entity Resolution (40%)
sections.content: Measures how confidently we matched user terms to data: | Scenario | Score | |----------|-------| | Exact match | 100% | | High fuzzy match (>95%) | 95% | | Good fuzzy match (85-95%) | 85% | | Fair fuzzy match (70-85%) | 70% | | Low match (<70%) | 50% | | No match needed | 100% |

sections.heading: Metadata Coverage (30%)
sections.content: Measures how well queried columns are documented: | Scenario | Score | |----------|-------| | All columns in Golden Metadata | 100% | | Most columns documented (>80%) | 90% | | Some columns documented (50-80%) | 70% | | Few columns documented (<50%) | 50% |

sections.heading: Execution Success (20%)

documents.title: MedDRA Hierarchy

sections.heading: Hierarchy Structure
sections.content: MedDRA organizes medical terminology in a 5-level hierarchy:

sections.heading: System Organ Class (SOC)
sections.content: The highest level, grouping by body system or etiology: | SOC | Description | |-----|-------------| | Cardiac disorders | Heart conditions | | Gastrointestinal disorders | Digestive system | | Nervous system disorders | Brain and nerves | | Skin and subcutaneous tissue disorders | Skin conditions | | Infections and infestations | Infectious diseases | **Total: ~27 SOCs**

sections.heading: High Level Group Term (HLGT)
sections.content: Groups related High Level Terms: **Total: ~337 HLGTs**

sections.heading: High Level Term (HLT)
sections.content: Groups related Preferred Terms: **Total: ~1,737 HLTs**

sections.heading: Preferred Term (PT)
sections.content: The standard term for coding adverse events: **Total: ~24,000 PTs**

sections.heading: Lowest Level Term (LLT)
sections.content: Synonyms and entry terms that map to PTs: **Total: ~82,000 LLTs**

sections.heading: Multi-Axial Classification
sections.content: A PT can appear under multiple SOCs:

sections.heading: Primary vs Secondary
sections.content: - **Primary SOC**: Main classification (used for primary coding) - **Secondary SOC**: Additional classification (for alternative grouping)

sections.heading: Coding Adverse Events
sections.content: 1. User reports: "My head hurts" 2. Match to LLT: "Head pain" (10019196) 3. Map to PT: "Headache" (10019211) 4. Store PT code in AEDECOD

sections.heading: Updating MedDRA
sections.content: MedDRA is updated twice yearly. Changes may include: - New PTs and LLTs - Deprecated terms (moved to new hierarchy) - Modified relationships

sections.heading: Next Steps
sections.content: - API Reference - Factory 3.5 Overview - Entity Extraction

documents.title: Understanding Confidence Scores

sections.heading: What is a Confidence Score?
sections.content: The confidence score (0-100%) indicates how reliable an answer is based on: - How well terms were matched - Whether columns are documented - If the query executed successfully - If results make sense

sections.heading: HIGH (90-100%) - GREEN
sections.content: **What it means:** - All terms matched exactly or with high confidence - All columns are well documented - Query executed without issues - Results are reasonable **What to do:** - Trust this result for reports and analysis - Safe to cite in documentation

sections.heading: MEDIUM (70-89%) - YELLOW
sections.content: **What it means:** - Some terms had fuzzy matches - Minor assumptions were made - May need verification **What to do:** - Review the methodology - Verify assumptions make sense - Consider rephrasing for higher confidence

sections.heading: LOW (50-69%) - ORANGE
sections.content: **What it means:** - Terms had low-quality matches - Significant assumptions were made - Results may not be accurate **What to do:** - Carefully review the SQL query - Check term resolution - Rephrase your question - Consult with data team

sections.heading: VERY LOW (<50%) - RED
sections.content: **What it means:** - Could not reliably answer the question - Terms were not found - Query may have failed **What to do:** - Do not use this result - Rephrase completely - Check if data exists - Contact support

sections.heading: Entity Resolution (40%)
sections.content: How well your terms matched the data: | Scenario | Score | |----------|-------| | "headache" matched exactly | 100% | | "headche" fuzzy matched (95%) | 95% | | "belly pain" → ABDOMINAL PAIN | 100% | | Term not found | 0% |

sections.heading: Metadata Coverage (30%)
sections.content: How well the queried columns are documented: | Scenario | Score | |----------|-------| | All columns in Golden Metadata | 100% | | Most columns documented | 90% | | Some documentation gaps | 70% |

sections.heading: Execution Success (20%)
sections.content: Whether the query ran properly: | Scenario | Score | |----------|-------| | Query succeeded with results | 100% | | Query succeeded, zero rows | 90% | | Timeout but recovered | 70% | | Query failed | 0% |

sections.heading: Result Sanity (10%)
sections.content: Whether results make sense: | Scenario | Score | |----------|-------| | Count is positive for existence query | 100% | | Percentage is 0-100% | 100% | | Zero results when unexpected | 70% |

sections.heading: Viewing Score Details
sections.content: Click the confidence badge to see breakdown:

sections.heading: When to Trust Results
sections.content: | Confidence | Use For | |------------|---------| | HIGH (90%+) | Reports, regulatory submissions | | MEDIUM (70-89%) | Internal analysis, verification needed | | LOW (50-69%) | Exploratory only, not for decisions | | VERY LOW (<50%) | Do not use |

sections.heading: Why is my confidence low?
sections.content: Common reasons: - Term not found in data - Typo in query - Using informal language - Data doesn't exist

sections.heading: Can I still use a MEDIUM result?
sections.content: Yes, but: 1. Review the methodology 2. Verify assumptions 3. Document any caveats

sections.heading: What if confidence is always low?
sections.content: Contact your administrator to: - Check if data is loaded - Verify metadata is approved - Rebuild dictionary indexes

sections.heading: Next Steps
sections.content: - Asking Questions Effectively - Example Queries - Chat Interface Guide

documents.title: Factory 4: Accuracy & Consistency Architecture

sections.heading: 1. Answer Accuracy Issues
sections.content: - SQL might be syntactically correct but **semantically wrong** - No verification that the generated SQL actually answers the question - Entity resolution might match wrong terms (e.g., "headache" → "sinus headache") - No feedback loop to learn from mistakes

sections.heading: 2. Query Coverage Limitations
sections.content: - System only handles queries it was "designed" for - No graceful handling of questions it can't answer - No clarification requests when ambiguous - No understanding of query variations

sections.heading: 3. Response Inconsistency
sections.content: - Confidence shown as: 95%, 0.95, "high", "5/5 stars" - all over the place - Different response structures from different code paths - No unified response contract

sections.heading: 4. No Memory/Learning
sections.content: - Same question asked differently = different answers - No learning from corrections - No session context (multi-turn conversations)

sections.heading: 1.1 Structured Query Analysis
sections.content: Instead of going directly from text to SQL, decompose the query first:

sections.heading: Phase 1: Foundation (Week 1-2)
sections.content: 1. **Unified Response Format** - Single response structure everywhere 2. **Confidence Standardization** - Integer 0-100, no variations 3. **Query Analysis Structure** - Decompose queries before SQL

sections.heading: Phase 2: Accuracy (Week 3-4)
sections.content: 4. **Answer Verification** - Verify before returning 5. **Clarification System** - Ask when uncertain 6. **Data-Driven Knowledge** - Learn from actual data

sections.heading: Phase 3: Intelligence (Week 5-6)
sections.content: 7. **Session Memory** - Remember conversation context 8. **Template Generation** - Data-driven query templates 9. **Learning from Corrections** - Improve over time

sections.heading: 10. Success Metrics
sections.content: | Metric | Current | Target | |--------|---------|--------| | Answer Accuracy | Unknown (~70%?) | > 95% | | Query Coverage | Limited patterns | Any clinical question | | Response Consistency | Multiple formats | 100% unified | | Clarification Rate | 0% (guesses) | 10-15% (asks when unsure) | | False Confidence | Common | Rare (<5%) |

sections.heading: Key Principles
sections.content: 1. **Understand before acting** - Parse query structure before generating SQL 2. **Ask when unsure** - Clarification > wrong answer 3. **Verify before responding** - Cross-check results 4. **One format always** - Consistent response structure 5. **Learn from data** - Don't hardcode, discover 6. **Remember context** - Use conversation history 7. **Be transparent** - Show how answer was derived

documents.title: Factory 4: Enterprise Architecture Design

sections.heading: Current vs Target State
sections.content: | Aspect | Current | Target | Priority | |--------|---------|--------|----------| | Retry Logic | None | 3x with exponential backoff | **CRITICAL** | | Circuit Breaker | None | Per-provider with auto-recovery | **CRITICAL** | | Request Tracing | None | UUID propagated through all steps | **CRITICAL** | | Error Recovery | Fail-fast | Graceful degradation | **HIGH** | | Observability | Basic logging | Structured logs + metrics | **HIGH** | | Rate Limiting | None | Token bucket per user/endpoint | **HIGH** | | Connection Pool | None | DuckDB connection pool | **MEDIUM** | | Config Management | Hardcoded | Externalized YAML + hot reload | **MEDIUM** | | Health Checks | Basic | Deep health with dependencies | **MEDIUM** |

sections.heading: Phase 1: Critical (Week 1-2)
sections.content: 1. **Request Context & Tracing** - Foundation for all observability 2. **Retry Logic for LLM** - Most common failure point 3. **Circuit Breaker** - Prevent cascading failures 4. **Structured Logging** - Debug production issues

sections.heading: Phase 2: High (Week 3-4)
sections.content: 5. **Metrics Collection** - Operational visibility 6. **Graceful Degradation** - Partial results vs. failures 7. **Rate Limiting** - Protect from abuse 8. **Health Checks** - Deployment readiness

sections.heading: Phase 3: Medium (Week 5-6)
sections.content: 9. **Configuration Externalization** - Clinical rules to YAML 10. **Connection Pooling** - DuckDB performance 11. **Cache Improvements** - Fuzzy matching, repair 12. **Hot Reload** - Config changes without restart

sections.heading: 8. Success Metrics
sections.content: | Metric | Current | Target | |--------|---------|--------| | Request Success Rate | ~90% | 99.5% | | P50 Latency | 5-10s | 3-5s | | P99 Latency | 60s+ | 15s | | Mean Time to Recovery | Manual | 40% |

sections.heading: Chaos Testing
sections.content: - Kill LLM provider mid-request - Inject network latency - Corrupt cache entries - Exhaust database connections

sections.heading: Load Testing
sections.content: - Sustained 100 QPS for 1 hour - Burst to 500 QPS for 5 minutes - Concurrent users: 50+

sections.heading: Failure Injection
sections.content: - LLM returns garbage SQL - Database locks - Cache corruption - Config file missing

documents.title: SAGE - Study Analytics Generative Engine

sections.heading: What is SAGE?
sections.content: SAGE (Study Analytics Generative Engine) is an enterprise-grade platform designed for the pharmaceutical industry. It allows clinical data scientists, biostatisticians, and medical writers to query clinical trial data using plain English. **Core Principle**: The AI acts as a **TRANSLATOR**, not an **EXPERT**. Mathematical calculations are performed by generated code, not by probabilistic AI inference.

sections.heading: Key Features
sections.content: | Feature | Description | |---------|-------------| | **Natural Language Queries** | Ask questions in plain English, get SQL-backed results | | **100% On-Premise** | All processing happens locally - no cloud dependency | | **GAMP 5 Compliant** | Category 4 validation with full audit trail | | **Confidence Scoring** | Every answer includes reliability indicators | | **Medical Terminology** | Built-in MedDRA and synonym support | | **Fuzzy Matching** | Handles typos and spelling variations |

sections.heading: Quick Links
sections.content: - :material-rocket-launch: **Getting Started** --- Install SAGE and run your first query :octicons-arrow-right-24: Installation Guide - :material-account: **User Guide** --- Learn how to ask questions effectively :octicons-arrow-right-24: User Guide - :material-cog: **Admin Guide** --- Configure and manage the platform :octicons-arrow-right-24: Admin Guide - :material-factory: **Architecture** --- Understand the Four Factories model :octicons-arrow-right-24: Architecture - :material-shield-check: **Compliance** --- GAMP 5 validation documentation :octicons-arrow-right-24: Compliance - :material-api: **API Reference** --- REST API documentation :octicons-arrow-right-24: API Reference

sections.heading: Architecture Overview
sections.content: SAGE uses a **Four Factories Model**: | Factory | Purpose | Input | Output | |---------|---------|-------|--------| | **Factory 1** - Data Foundry | Data ingestion | SAS7BDAT files | DuckDB database | | **Factory 2** - Metadata Refinery | Spec processing | Excel specifications | Golden Metadata JSON | | **Factory 3** - Dictionary Plant | Index building | Live data | Fuzzy matching indexes | | **Factory 4** - Inference Engine | Query processing | Natural language | SQL results | Learn more about the architecture :octicons-arrow-right-24:

sections.heading: Technology Stack
sections.content: | Component | Technology | |-----------|------------| | AI/LLM | Claude API | | Database | DuckDB | | Fuzzy Matching | RapidFuzz | | Medical Terms | MedDRA integration | | API | FastAPI | | UI | React + TypeScript | | Documentation | MkDocs Material | | Containerization | Docker Compose |

sections.heading: Support
sections.content: - **Documentation Issues**: Check the troubleshooting guide - **System Questions**: Use "Ask the System" feature in the chat interface - **Technical Support**: Contact your system administrator *SAGE - Making clinical data accessible through natural language*

sections.heading: User Decisions

sections.heading: Executive Summary
sections.content: SAGE (Study Analytics Generative Engine) is an on-premise clinical data AI platform that enables natural language queries against SDTM and ADaM clinical trial datasets. The system uses a RAG architecture with local LLMs to translate natural language to SQL/Python code, which is then executed deterministically against DuckDB.

sections.heading: Core Principle
sections.content: > **The AI acts as a TRANSLATOR, not an EXPERT.** Mathematical calculations are performed by generated code, not by probabilistic AI inference.

sections.heading: Key Features
sections.content: - 100% on-premise deployment (air-gapped capable) - Natural language to SQL translation - Confidence scoring with explanations - Human-in-the-loop metadata approval - Complete audit trail - GAMP 5 Category 4 validation approach

sections.heading: Overview
sections.content: Factory 1 transforms raw clinical trial data files into a queryable DuckDB database. This is the foundation that all other factories depend on.

sections.heading: Format Comparison
sections.content: | Format | Processing Speed | Features | Best For | |--------|-----------------|----------|----------| | | ⚡ Fastest | Direct load | Pre-processed data, large files | | | Medium | Date standardization, encoding detection | Original SAS datasets | | | Medium | Delimiter detection, type inference | Universal exchange | | | Slower | Legacy support | SAS transport files |

sections.heading: Schema Change Handling
sections.content: | Scenario | Handling | User Action | |----------|----------|-------------| | Same schema, new data | Direct replace | None - automatic | | New columns added | Replace + log change | Review new columns | | Columns removed | Replace + **WARNING** | Confirm removal | | Type change (compatible) | Replace + log (INT→DOUBLE) | Review change | | Type change (incompatible) | **BLOCK** + require confirmation | Must confirm | | Major schema change (>30%) | **BLOCK** + show diff | Must review & confirm |

sections.heading: Overview
sections.content: Factory 3 builds fuzzy matching indexes by scanning actual data values from DuckDB (Factory 1 output) and combining with metadata definitions (Factory 2). This enables typo correction and term resolution for query understanding in Factory 4. **Status:** ✅ Complete (December 2024) **Design Decision:** Semantic/embedding search has been intentionally excluded. Clinical data requires exact terminology matching using controlled vocabularies (MedDRA). Synonym matching is handled via the MedDRA hierarchy (Factory 3.5), not AI embeddings. **Critical Dependency:** Factory 4 (Inference Engine) uses Factory 3's fuzzy matching for entity extraction and typo correction.

sections.heading: Key Columns to Scan
sections.content: **Note:** Free-text columns (AETERM, MHTERM) and flag columns (Y/N values) are excluded to prevent false matches. | Domain | Columns | Purpose | Status | |--------|---------|---------|--------| | **AE** | AEDECOD, AEBODSYS, AESOC, AEHLT, AELLT | Controlled AE terms | ✅ | | **CM** | CMTRT, CMDECOD, CMCLAS, CMCAT, CMINDC | Drug names, classes | ✅ | | **LB** | LBTEST, LBTESTCD, LBCAT, LBSCAT, LBSPEC | Lab test names | ✅ | | **VS** | VSTEST, VSTESTCD, VSPOS, VSLOC | Vital signs | ✅ | | **DM** | SEX, RACE, ETHNIC, COUNTRY, ARM, ARMCD, ACTARM | Demographics | ✅ | | **MH** | MHDECOD, MHBODSYS, MHCAT | Medical history (controlled) | ✅ | | **ADSL** | SEX, RACE, ETHNIC, TRT01P, TRT01A, ARM, ACTARM, AGEGR1 | Analysis subjects | ✅ | | **ADAE** | AEDECOD, AEBODSYS, AESOC, AEHLT, AELLT, AEACN, AEOUT, AETOXGR | ADaM AE analysis | ✅ | | **ADLB** | PARAM, PARAMCD, PARCAT1, AVISIT, ANRIND, BNRIND | ADaM Lab analysis | ✅ | **Excluded Columns:** - , - Free text verbatim terms (not controlled vocabulary) -

sections.heading: Fuzzy Matching Examples (Tested & Verified)
sections.content: | User Input | Matched Value | Table.Column | Score | Use Case | |------------|---------------|--------------|-------|----------| | "headche" | Headache | AE.AEDECOD | 79.6% | Typo correction | | "hypertention" | Hypertension | ADAE.AEDECOD | 83.7% | Spelling error | | "nausea" | Nausea | AE.AEDECOD | 100% | Exact match | | "diabetis" | Diabetes mellitus | MEDDRA_HIERARCHY | 70%+ | Medical term typo | | "Myocardial infarction" | Myocardial infarction | AE.AEDECOD | 100% | Exact match | **Smart Scoring Algorithm:** - Prevents false positives (e.g., "Y" no longer matches "TYLENOL") - Length ratio filtering: value must be 40-300% of query length - Weighted scoring: ratio (40%) + token_sort (30%) + token_set (20%) + partial (10%) - Length similarity bonus for better matches **MedDRA Integration (Factory 3.5):** - Synonym matching via MedDRA hierarchy (PT → HLT → HLGT → SOC) - "fever" → finds "Pyrexia" via MedDRA lookup, not fuzzy matching

sections.heading: Module Architecture
sections.content: **Removed Modules (Design Decision):** - - Not needed; clinical data uses controlled vocabularies - - Not needed; MedDRA hierarchy handles synonyms - - Replaced by (fuzzy + MedDRA)

sections.heading: Component Details
sections.content: #### 3.1 Value Scanner () **Purpose:** Scan DuckDB tables and extract unique values from key columns. **Output format:** #### 3.2 Embedding Generator () **Purpose:** Create vector embeddings using Ollama's nomic-embed-text model. **Embedding document format:** #### 3.3 ChromaDB Store () **Purpose:** Manage ChromaDB collections for semantic search. **Collections:** | Collection | Contents | Purpose | |------------|----------|---------| | | All unique data values | Primary search | | | Metadata descriptions | Concept mapping | | | Custom synonym pairs | User-defined mappings | #### 3.4 Fuzzy Matcher () **Purpose:** Fast string matching using RapidFuzz library. **Matching strategies:** 1. **Simple ratio** - Basic Levenshtein similarity 2. **Partial ratio** - Best substring match 3. **Token sort ratio** - Word order insensitive 4. **Token set ratio** - Handles extra/missing words #### 3.5 Hybrid Matcher () **Purpose:** Combine fuzzy and semantic matching for optimal results. #### 3.6 Schem
